												TLDR; Cool concept, for a pretty niche community. Unfortnately there's no singleplayer mode and finding other players can take upwards of 10 minutes. Controls can feel unresponsive, but gameplay is genuinely fun. Online community feels dead and the game lacks varitey and customisability.I imagine they'd also be rolling out more updates in the future for more content, as it is there are 6 tracks and 6 different cars. When you start out you have no cars theres 6 to pick from and you have a choice of the first two as they are under 200K which is what you're given when you start out. The car models do look pretty good and was impressed with the details they were able to put into the models. After buying the car you want, take it to your garage and with whatever spare cash you have left you might be able to get an upgrade. The upgradeable aspects of your car are the brake, ECU, Exhaust, bodywork, suspension, KERS, spoiler, cooling and a few others. Upgrades will change the car in terms of fuel economy, top speed, accleration, drag, braking power and do matter. For instance the car I was using was kitted to last only about 25km's without pitting but I had constantly more power to use and ended out on top. Most races won't be longer than 50km's, also note drivers can be more fuel economic whilst driving.Once you're actually in-game it's pretty fun, you instruct your AI driver around and tell him when to use KERS, push harder, when to change the car's fuel map, pitstops and block. Controls can feel like they are unresponsive at times but that's due to driver stats which can be upgrades with experience points.Experience points can be used to increase the speed of certain aspects of your pitstop, increase the skill of your driver; how confident he is with braking and overtaking and how much speed he can carry through corners. You also have a manager who handles all your sponsorship contracts, you can give him greater chance of securing a contract and he can land better contracts for you aswell.Contracts themselves aren't overly fun to handle. You're given 10 time units and every action uses a certain amount of time units, time units are replentished after each race. Pretty easy mechanic but monotonous is a good way to describe sponsorship (10/10 immersion there). To actually land a deal you need to call up the sponsor which you might or might not get through to. Once you're in you can invite them out to dinner, send them gifts, give a presentation on your raceteam few other options I've forgotten. Each option will better the relationship between you and whomever you're chasing up.Once a you manage to squeeze out a contract offer you can change the aspects of the contract, how much you get paid, for how many races and what position you need to come in to adhere to those conditions of receiving the funds.All up I would recommend this game if they added more varitey and the online community was bigger, it's a fairly niche market so this game may never live up to it's full potential. In it's current state I wouldn't recommend this game.Apologies for the length of the review, it all got a bit out of hand. Cheers.

												PLAY THIS GAME IF YOU LOVE MOTORSPORT AND CIRCUIT RACINGThis game uniquely explores how important it is to properly manage tyres and fuel for pitstops as well as the importance of playing the strengths of cars to their fullest, you must determine when and where to push the car to its limits and when to drive it more economically. You'll be constantly doing math to figure out if you're under or exceeding your fuel quota and you will also be watching the tyre wear so you don't burn them out too fast and make the wear eat into your lap times.To add to the mix you can monitor what actions and strategies the opponents are employing throughout the race, this will sometimes make you rethink your strategy - will you let him pass and tail him or will you run your car at 100% and try to outrun him and if so, for how long? Keep in mind that running the car at full throttle eats into fuel and you'll finish most races with 0% - 5% fuel remaining so choose wisely.The tuning aspect of the game allows you to buy newer and better parts, some more suited for speed and power while others are suited better for handling and fuel economy, the challenge is to build a car that is well adapted for most situations and having strengths that can be used to secure wins. Your team can be upgraded too which consists of a Driver, the Pit Crew and lastly your Marketing Manager who is in charge of obtaining sponsorship deals.The game is still early in development phase and has numerous errors or design faults but it still brings a lot to the table, races are randomly selected and sometimes you will be put into a race where your cars setup has almost no chance of placing within the top 5 not even looking at first, this will be ironed out down the line but can detract from the experience. Pitstop bugs have happened before as well and I've had a few bugs with tyre selection costing me races in the past but I'm willing to overlook them for the time being while the developer fixes then; the developer is very active and open with progress on the steam forums so help is never too far away.And lastly a piece of advice for the people who are considering or have just bought the game and have yet to choose a car: buy the Raptor if you want an easier experience, buy the Avalanche if you want to grind your face into the wall but learn a lot more about strategy and have a greater challenge on the managing side of things. This game is ideal for those who know a lot about racecraft but are looking to expand their knowledge on race strategy.

Early Access Review
								In this game you become the manager of your own racing team. You won't find here popular car brands like Ferrari or Maserati but just a fictional racing cars.OverviewAs a team manager you can sign new sponsor offers and help the driver to drive around the track. By earning money out of every race you can then upgrade the car or buy a new color design. The racing itself is from 3rd person perspective so you see a very small cars. As a team manager you can instruct the driver to: overtake, overload, block or tail the following car. The second set of options is: KERS button, changing the engine's ECU fuel mapping or requesting the driver to make a pitstop. Instructing the driver to overtake the following car can be from the left or right side and it works pretty well but sometimes the AI fails causing strange situations. The rest of the options work pretty well.Game modesSingle race or cup mode - new in the game. In the cup mode you also have qualification lap which i felt lacking before. Cup mode provides you also some more fun because of strategy, because there are 3 races that are longer and therefore you can go on one pitstop or two. Balance The game is all the time on the same level. When you start there are many cars faster than you and some of them are slower. It means that after you do the upgrades to the car your car becomes more competetive and heads to the front of the opponents. After you upgrade your car to the maximum you fight for the first places. It means that after you do it your car is always in the front so if you don't have real players as the opponents, you almost always fight for win. There should be some racing categories or one type of car races to make it more interesting.MultiplayerIt's the first issue - because the game doesn't have singleplayer, the game is always looking for online players. Sadly almost all the time you compete with the bots and maybe 1-2 real players.Graphics & audioEverything looks very nice, has good sounds. The music becomes a little boring after 5 or 10 races but you can turn it off. Some optimalizations must be made to the game because of the high cpu/gpu usage, but so far it works nice.SummaryThere are still some bugs like for example disapearing wheels, lapped cars still fight like they were racing while they shouldn't. The game needs some work but the direction is so far very good and i can recommend this game. If you like racing games, you'll definetely like this one!Take a look at the stats of my profile here http://www.trackdaymanager.com/profile/?order=totalScore&nationality=Poland&teamID=1888

								Thumbs up for what it is. Was not exactly what I was expecting, but I am still enjoying it. This is not a hardcore management/simulation game, so know that before buying. To me, it feels more like an arcade game with a light management twist on it.Pros:- Lots of time to be sunk into this- Can be played when you only have a half hour or so (low single sitting commitment)- Quite a good looking game- While you don't directly drive the car, the "skills" present a highly engaging play style that doesn't have you just "kicking back and waiting"- When you are against bots, they seem to have a nice range of skillCons:- Low level of content (currently)- Have not seen more than 2 players in a race thus far- A bit too casual for a management, or a simulation, game (not sure which it wants to be, but leans towards casual for either category)- Have run quite a few races and only seen 2 of 5 tracks, making the content level feel even lower right now- Based on income rate and car cost, your "team" looks like it will be a single car/driver for longer than many would be willing to play the game (assuming you even can get another car - looks like you can)- No apparent way to "party" with someone- You don't know which track you will be racing ahead of time (randomly selected when you join a race) so you have to setup your car in the garage to be an overall setup- Pre-race setup consists of just choosing your tire type (3 basic choices, no fine adjustments)- In-game pit options are fuel refill level and tire type (again, no fine adjustments)Other Thoughts:- Price might seem a bit high right now with the lower amount of content. I am assuming that more will come. Regardless of the low content right now, if you can get into the game, I could see a very good hours/$ return.- A few small issues/bugs, but not bad for an early access and quite a lot better than many other games on early access (and even full release for that matter).- The in-race management is where you spend most of your time. Front office stuff takes a back seat in terms of time spent in game, and front office complexity is quite low.

												A game that had the potential, but just falls flat.It contains elements of what I wanted from a racing management simulator: sponsorship deals, six cars to choose from, a few good tracks, upgrades, stat point upgrades, leaderboards… That being said it's lacking in core features and polish. This lack of polish gives the game that Free 2 Play grind feeling with the price tag. Want to be competitive on the oval track? Better save up for that car that's good on ovals and then hope you have that car equipped when the game randomly selects the track for you. Granted, smart strategy can get you past these pitfalls, but it's still a major grind and you're fighting the RNG to get the track you want to race at.Most game modes are locked with a promise of a later release date. The game has its share of bugs (DNFs causing money loss in cups in following races, wrong tires being put on cars, bots getting stuck on walls and winning awards because of it, driver commands not working at times). Also, the netcode cannot handle large fields with 200ms latencies across players. In my opinion this game was released from early access way too soon.With the small player base, you're relegated to racing against bots 98% of the time. In the times we did get a league race together with 8-12 other players (the max field size is 16), the game would become unplayable. Laps wouldn't be counted, pit crew animations would completely vanish, and the lag was unbearable.I had dedicated 70+ hours to this game, helped build a subreddit, and tried to be an active member in the community.  Arctic Hazard Game Studio was very responsive and even quickly provided a patch to allow us all to race together as a group. While I commend them for that, it hasn't entirely redeemed a game that has such critical flaws. It does show they do care about Trackday Manager, but it got rushed to market before it was ready for showtime.It’s a shame, because I really wanted to like this game. There's not a lot of options in this genre and there really should be. It's something that if done well, could be a big hit.I recommend not buying this title, not even on a sale price in it's current state. If/when the developers do release a trial/F2P version of the game and you are interested, try that out first. If upcoming patches makes major changes to the game, I will be more than happy to re-review this.

												I bought this game thinking it would be the GTR equivalent of a football managing title. I was surprised to find that, although related to the managing genre in the various tasks you attend to when not actually racing, this is actually a deeply rewarding real-time pvp strategy game. This is how it works. Up to 16 players compete in races where you control the various strategic and tactical tasks that go towards running a racing team. Pitstop and tyre strategy is, of course, key to your success and winning a race on the last lap because of your fresh tyres is a thing of pure joy. But there's more still - you actually control a lot of your drivers actions. Engine mapping, KERs deployment, deliberately tail-gating to save fuel, whether you want your driver to attempt an overtake (and which side to try it on) or whether to drive defensively - all these things you control in real-time.However the real gem here is the multiplayer element. I've owned this less than a day and already I have had some amazing duels with budding team managers from all over the world. The community is fresh and happy with the game right now, which is always nice to be a part of.Don't get me wrong, this is clearly a rather niche title as well as an independent one (so not without it's annoying quirks or balancing issues) but for someone who spends every Sunday glued to the telly screaming at Ron Dennis that I could do his job so much better this is absolutely perfect and I love it.

Another arcade release, which this time got ported over to various computers of the day.  I was a spectrum guy, but I liked my friends C64 version better.Flash-forward quite a few years later -- this game also reminds me WRC Powerslide.  I played this on XBOX360,  of which I've been a gamer, or rather, a racer for quite some time. A year or so on, I feel I am at the same stage where the game has now been released and it's as enjoyable as ever but you get the feeling it left EA a month or two earlier than it should have.Overall the game is a great game and has that one more go appeal. I won't go into the specifics of what the game is about as there are many other reviews covering that aspect. I guess some of my thoughts may have been covered on the forum already, but I haven't read through each comment, so bear with me if I have said the obvious which has been covered.Pros:- I can't think of any other game like this on Steam- Great racing and your strategy can really make a difference.- Nice weather affects which really do change a game mid race.- Graphics are ideal for this type of game- Developers all be it small are in constant comms with the players and seem a dedicated bunch who have a proper passion for the game- The AI could be better but not bad either.- Able to play when there are not enough people online- Good community so far, bar the odd disconnector which I gather has now been patched- If you're a stoner, it's an ideal sit back and veg type game, with tiny mouse inputs throughout :)- Other race modes look great, but no dates on when they will be readyCons- Matchmaking leaves a lot to be desired. New players are already faced with meeting the 'new' cars and the issue becomes worse if you meet someone with a flying time as the AI will then also follow the fastest persons time, thus making it nigh on impossible to get anywhere.I understand the concern of matchmaking would make less people per race at this present time, but racing against bots your own level would help their progression for new players.- Lag, but I'm not sure if it's just me but it seems to be getting better?- Certain tracks suit certain cars. Not being able to make at least a change or two at the lobby stage to suit the track does hinder your chances.- Oval track (Sorry I hate this track)- Other car modes and cup features not being ready on launch.- Some bugs from EA are still here a year on.Recommendations- I know there are 2 sides to this one, but reverse grids in Quick Race as well as Cup to try to balance the game out. otherwise we're going to keep losing new players to refund which I have discussed on a previous post.- You should have the option when being slipstreamed to shake the car off rather than just have him tail you to save fuel and there is nothing you can do bar pit.- Reverse tracks to vary the races- More tracks and to balance out the tracks for speed and also handling of the cars- Make race distances varied with Sprint, normal and enduro distances. - Sort out the matchmaking- Try to introduce another compound for a tyre, medium? This will again add more strategy to the game. For me the game is more enjoyable from a strategic point of view than the actual racing.- Giving the player the option to make 1 or 2 changes max when you find out what track your on in the lobby would help things as there is nothing worse than having a handling set up to then find out you are on the oval. Obviously works the same way vica versa.- It needs more upgradeable parts to vary things. Overall I still stand by and give the game a positive review. I've been here since day one and have seen it when we had no servers for days and bugs that made the game totally unplayable.What we have now isn't perfect by any means and there is a long way to go, but give the devs a chance as this game could be a great game if we keep the number of players up and it ever improves.Anyway, that's my tuppence.

The maximum is that you will be pitted against bots; so your not stuck if no one is available.Cons:1) Not a fan of the sound track2) Hoped for more detailed car modding rather than "packages" 3) 2/4 races failed for one reason or another. In one my car got stuck trying to pit and just didn't move. In another the race never started. Had to quit to menu. 4) In another race I did not finish because I ran out of fuel... Now I may be wrong here, but why couldn't I just take a time penalty to get more fuel? Seems silly.5) Watching the cars felt a bit like watching RC cars race... Steering felt a little rigid.6) There's a NOS-like feature that fills up after every lap. That's a little 'gamey' if you ask me. (EDIT: I've been corrected that this is a real thing: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinetic_energy_recovery_system)7) You collect experience to spend on your team, but I never found a way to do that.8) You can lobby sponsers for contracts, which is neat, but it feels a bit arbitrary to build a high enough chance to get them to sign. I realize this was a simple way to simulate going out and getting contracts, but it's not terribly immersive and feels more like a mini game that is artificially handicapped by the 'TU' (time units). So its sorta like the TU are quarters and the contract 'game' is a bit of a slot machine you handicap in your favor over time.9) No camera controls. The follow cam stays on one side of the car, making it difficult to see where the car is going. You could zoom out, but that works dyanmicly so the camera is constantly panning in and out. That's not a huge issue... the main issue, is not knowing when a turn is coming to strategise your abilities (which side to overtake, when you might want to use your boost or overcharge..)10) I could be wrong, but it felt like you were racing against whomever was available regardless of skill level. That's fine, but it should be spelled out clearly that you might be up against someone with a tricked out car and a number of wins or fresh n00b. It's a little unfair to not know your competition. I expect that will get ironed out in the future, but again, its out of EA so who knows?I could go on, as I noted far more bugs and oddities than I listed, but I'm trying to be fair. All in all though, this game though I got it on sale wants me to believe its retail price is close to $30CAD. So I will compare it other games I've gotten at that pricepoint - and it really, really is not there. Mainly I was looking for a more serious racing manager... But as one reviewer said, whos warning I really should have heeded more strongly.. This is a game that would work better as an iOS app than a desktop racing manager. One thing is clear from looking at the game, it's clearly a work in progress. A number of modes for example are "coming soon", and there's also only 6 (albeit highly detailed) cars that are clearly modeled on real life cars. So one expects that in the future one will see more tracks, more cars and probably more features. This makes me think that someone of the game mechanics may simply be placeholders for future, better versions. In the end though, this isn't EA anymore. What you see, is what you get right now and for a game where the retail price is close to $30. or multiplayer only plus the severe bugs (pathing errors and non-starts are like getting uncooked food at a resturant. Unacceptable in 2016 at this pricepoint). That's too rich for me.I've requested a refund.tl;dr;Not a serious racing manager. Lacks content. Heavy on the bugs. Clearly a work-in-progress still. Priced too high, when it's current version would compete better with App Store games than other titles.

Project CARS, iRacing and many many more. I would say, over 10000 hours all together. More practise in virtual racing than every 'real' driver on track. So what do I think about TDM? I've bought it in early access phase, 29th May 2015. Played a lot and helped sorting out the bugs. Giving some ideas (like the qualifying in cup mode). It was very nice. Eating in front of the PC was a regular meal.Then there was release day. Everyone was online. Matches filled with up to 12 players. Most of the time lag-free. Very great races.How does it feel in comparison to project CARS, for example?Both are competitive racing games. In TDM you don't need a steering wheel, don't have to learn the basics about racing or 30+ tracks. You just buy your first car and go on track. Very few buttons to play the game. But very addictive gameplay, if you match up with competitive players.After the release, they changed something and you don't match up to a lot of players, even when a lot of players are in-game. But we communicate over steam and invite each other for cup races. And if you want to farm money for a new car, just go for bot races. You will need $14.000.000 to get all cars with all upgrades. Long-term-fun? Yes. I did it (buy all 6 cars) for three times now (2x early access and after release).Is this game for racers? Yes, and like every racing game, it is JUST for racers. Managers will go away very quickly. What is the graphics like? It suits the game. And the price. Go on YouTube and check some videos.Tell me about the bugs!We had a lot of detected bugs in ea and I have to say, the worst bugs are gone. And you can work around the most existing bugs. Which expands the gameplay (where to overtake at pit entry, sponsors patching and so on).How much is it worth? That's your own decision. I've read bad reviews with 2,5 hours of total play time. I've played 1000+ hours now. And at the actual state it is worth €20-25 to me.Maybe you should see this game as a slot racer. With 6 available tracks and 16 cars in race. Overtaking isn't easy and you have to stay calm even when a bot blocks you for half a lap - and then pits!Sponsors aren't fun, but you have to make more money!And please forget about the management part. It is just, but a very different racing game.

												Let me preface this review by reinterating this is an Live Launch Review. Having observed the game's development and at times being it's harshest critic. I am finally amending my review to reflect some of the progress and improvement that is TrackDay Manager today. There are still some glaring issues to be worked out, but the game is about 85% there after final release. Which is to say, I'm about 85% towards giving this title the thumbs up. I advise deciding yourself about this title. That said, here are some of the Pros and Cons of TrackDay Manager.Update Per Live Launch: 5 May 2016Pros:1: Overall concept and premise of the game is great.2: Graphics are solid and suit the concept and focus of the game.3: Customization of race cars (Not 100% of this content is ingame), both paintschemes and sponsor placement.4: Online Multiplay, with AI fillers when lacking enough human players.5: In race chat, allowing folks to chat pre-during-post race.6: Straight forward Upgrade and Skill system, easy to understand.7: Tons of Achievements that actually unlock useful and cool ingame content.8: Highly interactive and communicative development team of 4. So yea it's small but very dedicated team.Cons:1: Laggy netcode( Peer to Peer), resulting in lag spikes and sometimes adversely affecting race mechanics. Let me make clear, there are folks from all over the world playing this title and unfortunately the sheer distance between say North American players and European players often results in  laggy races. As of now, you are lucky to see another human player 1 out of maybe 10 races. Sadly MP is pretty much broken. 2: Lack of Career mode, MP Racing Leagues, League Management Tools, etc. There is a Leaderboard, which tracks National, Regional and Global Ranking. The lack of League Management tools really misses the mark in allowing folks to set up (In a convienent fashion) their own racing leagues. There is a "Cup" format newly added, which is a 3 random tracks mini-race series, queued up for just like single quick race. ***Edit*** Custom races have been added, which will allow leagues to form and manage themselves externally. Though there are plans for alternate mode and Reward Cup Series coming to the game in trhe future.3: Limited amount of vehicles (6) and tracks (6), albeit there is more content incoming, no ETA.4: Microtransactions where mentioned at point, seems this may be a dead issue and no longer in this game's future. We hope.5: Rudimentary Matchmaking. New(er) Drivers are not matched with Drivers whom have Max Skills and Maxxed out Cars for 50 races. After that, time to dine the freshbloods.6: Absence of an Open Game Lobby, where folks can hangout chat, swap strategies, ask advice, arrange races.7: Inability to preset custom setups for each track, like real race teams would in real life. One setup and random assigned race tracks, so you end up using the same setup for road courses and ovals alike, etc.8: The New GUI has some work to be done, as it does error and give improper information.9: This game should have been developed as a iOS/Android Application.10: Since launch the Developement team has been slow to patch and often breaking more than fixing. Which was a problem during Early Access also. Communication has also all but dried up, the Devs seem to be paying less attention this newly launched title.11: Arctic Hazard Games did little to promote this title, barely a whisper on any social media and ignored Early Access Player advice to ultilize Twitch and other Social promotion venues.In the End, avoid this already dead title. Was a great idea, implemented poorly.

												Trackday manager?! "What's this?!" I thought when I noticed it pop up on Steam. Much like many other motorsport/sim racing fans I crave a modern motorsports management game. I genuinely can't think of anything in very recent times that was worth playing. Sure, other management titles have come and gone, but they fail to live up to my expectations of what I want from a management game.I'd come to Trackday manager somewhat late, having noticed they had an open beta period. But as they say, better late than never!So in I go, full of hope that one of the voids of my gaming library had been filled..... and after some hours I can say I feel like it has been, mostly. Let me get in to the details.What do we get?Cars, multiple cars. Each one has its own pro's and cons. Power at the cost of handling, vice versa or a balance of the two? Other factors are in here like cooling. They all look like real cars that you would recognise but, I guess for licensing reasons, They have different names. We see this often in the modding world so it would make sense here.Car customisation is present. You can change how the car looks with painting it, bodywork changes, wheel rim changes and more. You can also change the internals of the cars to improve performance. Some of these performance parts are basically a trade off. Lose some points somewhere like cooling to gain more in top speed, that sort of thing.We also get sponsors. Sponsors can be given treats like meals or gifts to help persuade them to throw cash your way in return for plastering their logo all over your car. Sponsors that pay more are harder to convince. You better perform well and offer them the right treats to stand any chance of signing them.You can also improve your pit crew, driver and marketing guy. The better you do in races the more points you get to put in their skills, with a cash cost also, of course. Make the pit crew jack the car up faster or the driver use the breaks later and more, you get the picture.Manager, you say? So no driving?You don't actually get to drive the car in Trackday Manager, well, kind of....maybe. You're presented with a top-down 3D view of the circuit which in honesty is pretty nice looking in my opinion, for what it is. It's in the style of a super modern skidmarks (Really old game). You get to instruct your driver on what to do in a live way, as if you were on the pit wall and literally hand feeding them instructions. Push hard, pass left, defend etc etc. Added to this there is also a KERS/boost button. You get a certain amount of boost per lap, adding to the required strategy & thought.Weather and pit strategy matter. You will use fuel and tyres, you will need to actually think about strategy. I have been caught out on drying circuits not pitting soon enough for dry tyres and killing my soft dry tyres, using them for too long. This adds a perfect and much needed dynamic for this sort of game.Always online?!the game requires an internet connection. Lots of complaints about this. I can't say I'm bothered. Though I think it needs one to even start, which I understand being an issue.You can have up to 16 players in a race. Multiplayer is where this game comes alive, it's absolutely fantasic. Being on voice comms with a friend(s) and in a race/championship matching up your cars, drivers and tactics against one another can provide hours of genuine entertainment and belly-laughs. It's worth noting, though, that, races can be full of AI unless you're grouped with a friend. I'm not sure whether this is a matchmaking issue or a lack of players. Fortnightly stats show 1,059 players have started the game in Steam. This could maybe be the issue. I feel it deserves more attention from gamers.So, what do you think?I think Trackday Manager is an attractive and worthy purchase for any racing fan. Especially at the current price of £8.99, well worth it. Best played with friends grouped up and racing together as it can feel a little like a grind if attacking it solo after a few hours.

												I could've gone on for days about this game, but let me put it this way:Yes, it has less content than Motorsport Manager, and on the face it, with only six cars and six tracks, it appears relatively repetitive. Thing is, you can have your strategy all worked out, but, like a classic Top Gear challenge, something is destined to go wrong. It could be a sudden thunder storm, or The Stigs Virtual Cousin could make an appearance. You have to consistently keep an eye for absolutely everything, just as in every other driving game - how are you doing on tyres and fuel, what is your opposition doing, how do you predict the weather will be for your last stint. Then it's back to the studi- I mean garage, analyse the event and change your car setup accordingly or maybe change car completely. Make your pit crew better to save time in the pits. Have your marketing manager contact more sponsors to bring in even more dough to spend on upgrades, which in turn will help make you more competitive and earn even more lovely monies.All that for about 1/3 of Motorsport Manager. It's not bad value when you think about it.What this is, is easy to understand and play, but difficult to master.Would I recommend it? If you enjoyed Gran Turismo 5's B-Spec mode, the team/sponsor management aspects of Race Driver: Grid, can enjoy a game that isn't about F1 cars and can live with the shortcomings a small development team - as should be expected - does have, then yes. Definitely.
